ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about African literature, Yiddish literature, modernism, postmodernism, and a host of other literary movements. Prof. Caplan's reading list was great - totally different than any other class I've ever taken.
I learned how to read literature in cultural and historical context and to think about issues of modernity and traditionalism

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The syllabus was full of fascinating books that I would have never heard of it not for this course. I really liked that Prof. Caplan related all the material to events and movements occurring throughout the world during the years they were written. I also liked that instead of having students do 15 minute presentations, which are usually boring, Prof. Caplan met with students to craft informative presentations that facilitated group discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course (although unfortunately, Prof. Caplan is a visiting professor). You learn a ton about literature you would never have otherwise heard of, and Prof. Caplan relates everything we read to greater social and political movements. Prof. Caplan takes a lot of time to help students he looks at early essay ideas and meets with students one-on-one to discuss their work and the literature. The workload is real but reasonable. You will learn so much!
